Text: The Pupil asks: `At whose wish does the mind sent forth proceed on its errand? At whose command does the first breath go forth? At whose wish do we utter this speech? What god directs the eye, or the ear?'  The Teacher replies: `It is the ear of the ear, the mind of the mind, the speech of speech, the breath of breath, and the eye of the eye. When freed (from the senses) the wise, on departing from this world, become immortal.  `The eye does not go thither, nor speech, nor mind.

`It is thought to be known (as if) by awakening, and (then) we obtain immortality indeed. By the Self we obtain strength, by knowledge we obtain immortality.  `If a man know this here, that is the true (end of life); if he does not know this here, then there is great destruction (new births). The wise who have thought on all things (and recognised the Self in them) become immortal, when they have departed from this world.'

Then they said to Indra: `O Maghavan, find out what sprite this is.' He went towards it, but it disappeared from before him.  Then in the same space (ether) he came towards a woman, highly adorned: it was Uma, the daughter of Himavat. He said to her: `Who is that sprite?'

She replied: `It is Brahman. It is through the victory of Brahman that you have thus become great.' After that he knew that it was Brahman.  Therefore these Devas, viz.
